articles.headline: For Those Facebook Left Behind
articles.snippet: A primer on social networking sites for those who don’t know a Yelp from a FriendFeed.
articles.abstract: A primer on social networking sites for those who don’t know a Yelp from a FriendFeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, the standards editor at The New York Times wrote a memo that shocked — shocked! — bloggers everywhere. He asked Times writers to avoid using the word “tweet” (as in, “to say something on Twitter”).

articles.headline: BP Tries to Reassure Shareholders
articles.snippet: BP’s chief executive has been talking to shareholders to convince them that BP can pay for the Gulf of Mexico oil spill without jeopardizing growth.
articles.abstract: BP’s chief executive has been talking to shareholders to convince them that BP can pay for the Gulf of Mexico oil spill without jeopardizing growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 10 weeks, BP has focused on the challenge of plugging its gushing oil well a mile below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico. It has also struggled to placate angry gulf residents and government officials and reassure a public frustrated by the company’s inability to stop the spill.

articles.headline: Owner of Exploded Rig Is Known for Testing Rules
articles.snippet: Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, has pursued profits while testing local laws, and kept up questionable ties in Myanmar, Iran and Syria.
articles.abstract: Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, has pursued profits while testing local laws, and kept up questionable ties in Myanmar, Iran and Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: Transocean is the world’s largest offshore drilling company, but until its Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April, few Americans outside the energy business had heard of it. It is well known, however, in a number of other countries  for testing local laws and regulations.

articles.headline: V.A. Is Easing Rules to Cover Stress Disorder
articles.snippet: New rules on filing claims for post-traumatic stress disorder could affect hundreds of thousands of war veterans.
articles.abstract: New rules on filing claims for post-traumatic stress disorder could affect hundreds of thousands of war veterans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government is preparing to issue new rules that will make it substantially easier for veterans who have been found to have post-traumatic stress disorder to receive disability benefits, a change that could affect hundreds of thousands of veterans from the wars in Iraq, Afghanistan and Vietnam.

articles.headline: Facebook Makes Headway Around the World
articles.snippet: In country after country, Facebook is cementing itself as the social networking leader.
articles.abstract: In country after country, Facebook is cementing itself as the social networking leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sergey Brin, a Google founder, takes issue with people who say Google has failed to gain a foothold in social networking. Google has had successes, he often says, especially with Orkut, the dominant service in Brazil and India.

articles.headline: For Democrats, Debt Debate and Familiar Ring of Disunity
articles.snippet: The Democrats’ argument over fiscal policy represents the churning of a cultural fault line that has defined and destabilized the party’s politics for years.
articles.abstract: The Democrats’ argument over fiscal policy represents the churning of a cultural fault line that has defined and destabilized the party’s politics for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In case you’ve been out of the country for the last 25 years and were afraid that nothing had stayed the same, here are some current events you may find comforting: Bon Jovi is touring. The Russians are spying on suburbia. And Democrats in Washington are squabbling over the direction of their party.

articles.headline: Russian Spy Suspects Plead Guilty as Part of a Swap
articles.snippet: Suspects in a Russian spy ring pleaded guilty, facilitating a prisoner exchange between Russia and the United States and  ending an episode that had threatened relations.
articles.abstract: Suspects in a Russian spy ring pleaded guilty, facilitating a prisoner exchange between Russia and the United States and  ending an episode that had threatened relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States sealed an agreement on Thursday to trade 10 Russian agents arrested last month for four men imprisoned in Russia for alleged contacts with Western intelligence agencies, bringing to a quick conclusion an episode that threatened to disrupt relations between the countries.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: June Sales Were Tepid at Low End and High
articles.snippet: Retail sales rose 3.1 percent in June compared with June of last year, slightly lower than estimates compiled by Thomson Reuters.
articles.abstract: Retail sales rose 3.1 percent in June compared with June of last year, slightly lower than estimates compiled by Thomson Reuters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Department stores are attracting shoppers again, but not enough to indicate a full recovery for all retailers.
